WEPS:document_set.name: Brenda_Clark
WEPS:document_set.WEPS:document:
Brenda Clark didn't know very much about turtles when she was asked to illustrate a picture book called Franklin in the Dark in 1986. The story about a turtle who was afraid to go into small, dark places made her smile, so she set out to learn all about turtles - how they walked, where they lived, what they ate. She designed a woodland world and filled it with fun animal characters, including, of course, Franklin, who is a mix of a box turtle and a Galapagos tortoise.

Since that first book, Brenda and writer Paulette Bourgeois have created more than thirty Franklin the Turtle stories, winning fans worldwide.

When Brenda was little, she spent most of her time drawing and coloring. After high school, Brenda decided that she wanted to learn more about art. She graduated with honors from the illustration program at Sheridan College in Ontario, Canada. Brenda illustrated many magazine articles and books for several years before meeting up with Kids Can Press. Kids Can asked her to illustrate Christopher and the Dream Dragon. She worked on several more books before she was matched with Paulette - and Franklin!

When she first set out to draw Franklin, Brenda wanted to make sure that she captured Franklin's emotions. Now, each time she draws Franklin, she spends lots of time working on his expressions and poses until she gets him just right.

She also likes to include lots of fun details in her pictures. Franklin has a turtle clock on his bookcase and likes his pancakes dripping with maple syrup - and a handful of ladybugs.

Brenda begins every new picture of Franklin with a tiny sketch in pencil. Then, she does many rough drawings. Finally, she uses watercolors to fill in her pictures.

Brenda creates art for other books, too. The designs are sometimes very different from her Franklin style. While Brenda likes the excitement of working on other stories, she never forgets about the little turtle who brought her out of her shell.

Franklin the Turtle

Brenda Clark: Illustrator
Born in Toronto, Ontario

Birth date: February 10, 1955

Married to Robert Courtice with one child.

Home: Port Perry, Ontario

An honors graduate from Sheridan College's Illustration Program in 1977, Brenda has been freelancing for publishers of educational materials. She has also illustrated for Chickadee Magazine. Since 1984, Brenda has been spending her time illustrating picture books. 

She has worked hard to capture a believable character in Franklin and also in his friends, wanting them to show a range of emotions to reflect the mood created in the story. Brenda is a meticulous artist, taking care with every brush stroke, and thinking about the light source for each page. 

She encourages children to draw every day, because that is how her drawing improved. She also recommends that if you don't know how something looks or can't remember, go find out. That way your pictures will be the best they can be and the most interesting.

Brenda Clark, Anthropology Instructor

I am a bioarchaeologist and physical anthropologist specializing in human skeletal anatomy. In addition to teaching in these fields, I enjoy the applied work they offer in cultural resource management and forensic investigations.

IMDb Info

Biographical Information
Birthday: February 10, 1955
Birth Place: Port Hope, Ontario

Notes
  • Spouse: Robert Courtice, Has one child
  • An honours graduate from Sheridan College's Illustration Program in 1977, Brenda began by freelancing for publishers of educational materials. She has also illustrated for Chickadee magazine. Since 1984, Brenda has been spending most of her time illustrating picture books. She has worked hard to capture a believable character in Franklin and also in his friends, wanting them to show a range of emotions to reflect the mood created in the story. Brenda is a meticulous artist, taking care with every brush stroke and giving life to the illustrations by using light and shadow for a three dimensional effect. She encourages children to draw every day if possible. Keep your drawings and look back at them over time to see how much you have improved. She also recommends that if you don't know or can't remember how something looks, visit the library and get photo references, but never trace. Just observe carefully with your eyes. That way, your pictures will be the best they can be and you will get practice drawing anything and everything.

For Franklin in the Dark, Paulette and illustrator Brenda Clark worked separately and didn't get to meet until after the book was published. When it was released in 1986, Franklin in the Dark sold an astounding 10,000 copies and Franklin became a star!

Paulette was surprised when Kids Can Press asked her to write another Franklin the Turtle story. Franklin's second tale, Hurry Up, Franklin, was published in 1989. Paulette and Brenda have since created dozens more Franklin the Turtle books. Kids can read about Franklin's adventures in 31 countries and 17 languages, including Hebrew, Greek and Turkish!

Although Paulette is best known for the Franklin the Turtle books, she has written other titles for Kids Can Press, including the In My Neighborhood series and two books in the Starting with Space series.

Paulette also likes to make quilts. She decided to mix writing and quilting in her new story, Oma's Quilt, a picture book to be published in 2001.

Paulette now has four children, a dog named Dixie Lee Ragtime, shelves filled with books and lots of quilts on her walls. But she doesn't have a single, live turtle - anywhere.

Review

reviewed by Brenda Crawford-Clark, author of Body Sense : Balancing Your Weight and Emotions

As an author and therapist I'm pretty picky about what I recommend. But I can tell you that Caron Goode's book is one that I recommend to all of my clients and friends. She provides powerful insight and hands-on techniques to help parents reach their goal of raising self-confident, happy children who feel free to follow their dream. In a world so focused on fear, this book should go to the top of your purchase list.

Readers learn how to motivate children through mindbody techniques that foster emotional openness, increase releaxation, and support the development of intelligence, emotional literacy and intuition.

Clicking on the "order here" link will take you to the purchasing page on Amazon.com to make it easy for you to buy the books you like.  Other links are provided if there are more toys or products to coincide with the books.

Franklin by Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark (4 and up) (Scholastic) as on the Nickelodeon TV show, Franklin is a turtle. Together with his woodland friends, Bear, Beaver, Goose, Owl and Snail, Franklin deals with the fears, joys and adventures of growing up. Subjects include the dark, thunderstorms, sleepovers, bad days, riding a bike, wanting a pet, fibbing and more. The stories are well written and the illustrations are clear and colorful.  The Franklin books are a big hit with the first-graders I read to! Follow this link to see what Franklin books and products are available to order from Amazon.com.

Franklin IS BOSSY - When Franklin wants to tell all his friends what they will play and how they will play, Bear and the others decide they don't want to play with Franklin because he's being too bossy.  Franklin learns the lesson of playing well with others and taking turns. Order here.

Franklin WANTS A PET - Franklin would love to have a pet to take care of and love. There are so many pets to choose from and everyone makes suggestions to help Franklin but Franklin has a special pet in mind.  Franklin learns about decision making and responsibility.  Order here.

Franklin PLAYS THE GAME - Franklin really wants his soccer team to win just one game, but it's always Bear's team that wins.  Being assured that doing your best and having fun doesn't make Franklin feel any better. Franklin's teammates each try hard to score and win, but it is when they put their collective talents together that they learn the meaning, and the rewards of teamwork. Order here.


Franklin's BLANKET - When Franklin loses his favorite blue blanket, his family and friends offer him their favorite objects to help make him feel better. But only the return of his beloved blanket and the assurance that it will always have a place in his home and his heart make Franklin happy. Order here.

Franklin HAS A SLEEPOVER - Franklin is excited when his mother gives him permission to have Bear over for his first sleepover.  Bear and Franklin have a great time until it is time to go to sleep.  Suddenly, Bear is sad when he realizes the routine is not the same, he misses his room and mom is not there to say goodnight to his bunny.  Franklin offers comfort and soon they are looking forward to Franklin staying over at Bear's house.  Franklin and Bear learn that new experiences can sometimes be scary, but well worth the effort!  Order here(audio cassette).

Franklin's HALLOWEEN - Franklin is all excited about the coming Halloween costume party. Franklin and his friends all work to keep their costumes a secret, but Franklin is sure that Bear will be a ghost.  Then the big night arrives and Franklin learns that Bear is sick and couldn't make it to the party.  So who is the big ghost that zooms over Franklin's head?  Franklin faces his fear and shares with his friend.  Order here.


Franklin RIDES A BIKE - Franklin feels bad because his friends can all ride their bikes and Franklin still can't ride without training wheels.  Franklin believes that everything comes easily for the others but not for him.  When he remembers how his friends have all had difficulties learning different things (Badger had trouble learning to swim under water, Beaver couldn't swing on the monkey bars, and Fox couldn't hit the baseball) he realizes that they overcame it by trying again and again.  Franklin learns that some things are harder than others, and that he must never stop trying.  Order here.

FINDERS KEEPERS FOR Franklin - When Franklin finds a camera with no name on it, he gets so excited that he uses the camera to take pictures of his friends.  "Finders keepers" his friends tell him, but Franklin knows he should do more to find the owner and the return the camera.  Franklin learns how good it feels to do the right thing. Order here.

Franklin AND THE THUNDERSTORM - Franklin is afraid of thunderstorms.  When one hits while he and his friends are at Fox's house, Franklin doesn't want to come out of his shell.  Each of the animals has their own story about what causes thunder and lightning, and soon Franklin is comfortable enough to come out and play with the others until the storm is over. Franklin learns how to overcome his fear.  Order here.


Franklin GOES TO THE HOSPITAL - When Franklin gets hurt playing soccer, Dr. Bear says he needs an operation to fix a crack in his shell.  Everyone tells Franklin he is very brave, but inside Franklin is afraid.  When Dr. Bear needs x-rays, Franklin is afraid they will reveal how he really feels inside.  Franklin learns that it is okay to be afraid and what bravery really means. Order here.


Franklin's BABY SISTER - Franklin loved Spring but this year would be special because he was going to be a big brother. As Franklin eagerly awaits the arrival of the baby, he learns about the awakening of the earth and the joy of new life.  Order here.

Franklin AND THE BABY - Franklin thinks Bear is lucky when he learns he is going to be a big brother, but when his baby sister is born Bear begins to think he can't do anything right and his parents don't pay attention to him anymore.  Franklin and Bear learn that babies take extra attention because they can't do anything for themselves yet, but that they are loved just as much as ever!  Order here.

Franklin SAYS SORRY - Franklin promises to keep a secret for Bear, but when Franklin makes the mistake of telling just one friend, he soon realizes that everyone makes the same mistake and Bear's secret surprise is ruined.  Franklin tries to talk to Bear and play with him, but Bear ignores his friend until Franklin says he is sorry.  Franklin learns the importance of saying you're sorry when you do something wrong. Order here.

Franklin's BICYCLE HELMET - Franklin picks out a flashy new bicycle helmet that he just loves.  But when he overhears his friends talking about the new style of helmet with the red light on top, Franklin hides his helmet and his bike for fear of being teased.  Rabbit shows Franklin that it is what you think that matters and Franklin goes on to participate in the bike safety rally and be commended for his safety helmet.  Order here.

Franklin HELPS OUT - Franklin and his friends are on a nature hike.  Snail doesn't move very fast so Franklin decides to be helpful and give Snail a hand.  But Franklin is a little too helpful and Snail wants to do things for himself.  When Franklin lets his friend do for himself, he is surprised to learn that Snail can do things even a helpful turtle can't! Order here.

Franklin AND THE HERO - Dynaroo the kangaroo is Franklin and Snail's favorite superhero.  When they hear that Dynaroo will be signing her new book at the local bookstore, they plan to be there first thing in the morning.  When a neighbor is in trouble and needs help, Franklin and Snail stay to help and miss the signing.  Franklin and Snail soon learn what it really means to be a superhero and how good it feels to help others.  Order here.

Short Biography:
 

Employment History:  
1972-1979 UK MoD Research Establishment - Fourier Optics
1984-1986 Physics Lecturer, CEGEP Dawson College, Montreal
1986-1997 Medical Physicist, McGill University Hospitals
1997-present Medical Physicist, BC Cancer Agency

Research:

Area:   Radiation Therapy Physics
Topics:   Stereotactic Radiosurgery Planning
 
Research Summary
 
Stereotactic Radiosurgery is the ablation of small lesions in the brain with a single dose of high energy radiation. The success of this technique relies on avoidance of morbidity by minimisation of dose delivered to healthy tissue outside the target volume. Dosimetric studies are being performed to ensure optimisation of the parameters of the treatment delivery process to achieve this goal. The data is then correlated with tumor response and complication rate in the surrounding normal tissue.

Stereotactic Radiotherapy is the irradiation of small lesions in the brain with a tumouricidal dose of high energy radiation delivered over a period of several days or weeks with the aim of sparing healthy tissue close to the treatment volume. This is a high precision technique requiring accurate positioning of the patient for daily treatment. We are studying various aspects of this treatment including the reproducibility of the patient positioning system to verify the precision of dose placement.

Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy is the irradiation of complex shaped lesions with inverse planned, intensity modulated beams. Work in this area focusses around the spatial resolution requirements of the treatment delivery system to ensure a match between the lesion shape and the deliverable dose. Also under investigation is a novel method of dose delivery which will improve the conformality of dose to the target volume and reduce dose delivered to healthy surrounding tissue.

Editorial Reviews
From School Library Journal

PreS-K--Franklin Tortoise's anxiety as he senses an approaching thunderstorm is not appeased by Fox, Hawk, or Beaver, all of whom find inclement weather rather exciting. They reassure their friend that there is nothing to worry about once they are inside a snug burrow. Franklin, nevertheless, retreats into his shell until they tell him that the noise from thunder is just cloud giants bowling and playing drums in the sky and that lightning is made by cloud giants turning their lights off and on. Owl, though, has a more scientific explanation that amazes them all. Soon the storm subsides and a rainbow appears. The simple story is accompanied by garishly bright illustrations of somewhat precious animals at play. Patricia Polacco's Thundercake (Philomel, 1990) addresses the subject with considerably more charm, but for additional material, where Franklin books are popular, this one might be an option.

Sally R. Dow, Ossining Public Library, NY

Copyright 1998 Cahners Business Information, Inc.

 --This text refers to the Hardcover edition.

5 of 5 people found the following review helpful:

"WE HAVE NOTHING TO FEAR BUT FEAR ITSELF.", May 13, 2002
Reviewer:   Kellye Werner "Soaring Heart" (Flying free) - See all my reviews
     
FRANKLIN AND THE THUNDERSTORM is a colorful, entertaining, imaginative young reader book dealing with a relevant issue--FEAR. We all have them so this young reader book is sure to grab the child's attention. There is conflict and character growth, the formula for a great story a child will remember and ask for again.

Franklin's mother sends a reluctant and nervous turtle dressed in galoshes and a rain hat, carrying an umbrella, over to his friend, Fox's house as a storm begins to brew. When he arrives, there are three other animals there sharing their opinions about the approaching thunderstorm such as: "My fur feels funny," says Fox. "My feathers get all ruffled," says Hawk. "I can smell a storm coming," says Beaver sniffing. No one seems to be scared but Franklin. But he is scared enough for all four of his buddies! The storm hits full force and they all run inside. When the power goes out Franklin is so terrified he retreats inside his shell and no kind of coaxing on anyone's part, even treats from Mrs. Fox, will get him out. So Franklin's friends use their imaginations and begin talking about the CLOUD GIANTS. Whether the Cloud Giants are bowling or playing drums in the sky (thunder,) swinging from chandeliers or turning their lights on and off (lightning,) the illustrations are what make the story so great. Beaver quotes Mr. Owl's factual definition of thunder and Franklin, by this time, is out of his shell and smiling. Fox and his friends go back outside and Franklin discovers a rainbow. What Franklin say at the ending rounds out this very special story.

*You should buy this for the funny illustrations of the Cloud giants and what Franklin says about rainbows alone. Wonderful short story for ages 4-8. I got a set of 4 Franklins in a book club for my young daughter and this is her favorite.

Franklin Fibs, September 30, 2003
A Kid's Review
This story was about a turtle named Franklin who lies to his friends. Franklins friends can all do something unique like climbing the highest tree, flying over the berry patch without flapping their wings, and chopping down a tree with using just their teeth. Well Franklin gets really jealous so he makes up a lie. He tells all of his friends he can eat 76 flies in the blink of an eye. The lesson this book teaches is not to lie. The age level of this book is about from ages 5-8. I liked this book because it teaches an important lesson that all children need to learn.

A Gentle Friend, November 27, 2001
Reviewer:   A reader
Feeling overwhelmed by the amazing accomplishments of his friends, Franklin wants to feel important, too. Brashly he fibs about how many flies he can eat in the blink of an eye. Then he must deal with the consequences of his lie. As Franklin learns about proper conduct and relationships, children can identify with the situations of this gentle friend. They may need help in understanding what a fib or a lie is. Now if the authors would only write about Franklin's Awful Word or Franklin is Rude.

Brenda Clark
“I love making the impossible seem real!”
books by
Brenda Clark
Brenda today.
 Birthplace?
Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

Birthday?
February 10th.

Where do you live now?
Port Hope, Ontario.

When did you start drawing?
As an infant. Just kidding. Can't remember, so I must have been a toddler.

Do you have any tips for young creators?
Keep a sketchbook and draw, draw, draw every day. Even simple objects like your toothbrush. Draw people at bus stops and while you're waiting in line for something. If you can't draw, then observe. Use your eyes like a camera and really try to remember what you see. Get inspired from other people's art, but don't try to draw like them.

What is your favourite book?
Right now, I'm reading Harry Potter. Wonderful.
Brenda as Glenda the good witch.

Brenda Clark

Education

B.S. in Chemical Engineering (Oklahoma State University '91)

What was your career path? (what positions/companies, etc.)

  • Engineer

What challenges/obstacles have you met and how did you master these?

  • Challenge - Dealing with colleagues that are not comfortable with younger women and did not accept my recommendations as valid.
  • Response - I sharpened my people management skills (working well with others is essential in the workplace.) I also sought advice from my supervisor and human resources representative for ideas on how to work with the situation.

What advice do you have for women in your field?

Be honest with yourself, do what is right, and trust your abilities and skills.

What comments do you have about balancing career and personal life?

Everyone is different and has to determine the right balance for career and family. If you work for a company that is not family-friendly, set out to make change happen!

DREAM JOB

Brenda Clark: Bringing books to life

By Linda White
Special to The Toronto Sun

For the illustrator of the hugely popular Franklin the Turtle children's books, the path to success has been much like that of her beloved character: slow and steady.

Children's book illustrator Brenda Clark, and some of the work she has completed.
"It really is a dream come true for an illustrator, but I wouldn't say it came with ease," says Brenda Clark, 47. "There were many years of ups and downs."

The Port Perry resident credits her father for nurturing her love of art and researching career opportunities as a commercial artist. She honed her skills at Don Mills Collegiate in North York before taking a three-year illustration and design program at Sheridan College in Oakville.

Clark began freelancing for educational publishers in 1977, within three weeks of graduating. She spent two years as an in-house illustrator with Ginn Publishing in Toronto, working nights on other freelance projects, including Chickadee magazine.

"I tried a bit of everything, but felt most comfortable with books," Clark says. "I didn't have the editorial bent you need to work with magazines.

Also, you get a lot more time to illustrate books and I'm not a quick illustrator. Books are usually around a while, and that's nice too."

Freelancing gave Clark a solid foundation. "I was able to do many types of work because I was very versatile. I never searched for that one style. My technique changes with every book."

After showing her portfolio to Kids Can Press, Clark was asked to illustrate Christopher and the Dream Dragon by Allen Morgan. She worked on several more books before tackling Franklin in the Dark by Paulette Bourgeois, a story about a turtle afraid to go into small, dark places, including his own shell.

Clark devoted the next nine months to creating Franklin, his woodland world and animal friends. It was difficult deciding how the turtle should look and he went through numerous changes. "Franklin didn't look very attractive in the beginning and the publishers told me so," Clark says. "I'm glad they did."

At the time, neither Clark nor the author had any idea there'd be more than one book. They didn't even meet until after the book was published in 1986, when it sold an astounding 10,000 copies. The pair has gone on to create more than 30 Franklin stories, available in 31 countries and in 17 languages.

The success of the stories was underscored when Nelvana, a leading animation company based in Toronto and now owned by Corus Entertainment, approached Franklin's creators and publisher about developing a TV series and licensing merchandise.

Clark continues to freelance with Kids Can Press, working by contract from book to book. She also has creative input in the animated books based on the TV series, along with Franklin merchandise. As an adjunct professor with Sheridan College, she encourages students to follow their dreams of becoming artists.

"I'm still learning. I look back at my first books and see all sorts of things I'd like to change," says Clark, who advises aspiring artists to draw every day. "I don't think I was better than any other kid my age. The fact that I kept at it made the difference."

Clark is taking time off from illustrating books to work on other projects, including assisting in the set design of a new Franklin play produced by Tanglewood Family Entertainment for audiences across North America.

"That will be fun," Clark says. "It's another way of bringing the books to life."

(Linda White is a freelance writer based in Brooklin, Ont., and can be reached at linda.white@rogers.com.)

Kama Coast to Coast 2003
Celebrating Literacy Coast to Coast

For the Love of Reading | Back to list
Prince Albert, Saskatchewan ~ October 18, 2003

On Saturday October 18, 2003, the Prince Albert Literacy Network hosted their second annual "For the Love of Reading" community reading festival. This group's second festival was yet another resounding success, with Brenda Clark, the acclaimed illustrator of the Franklin the Turtle books, sharing her love of reading with over 300 kids, parents and kids at heart in the community of Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

The festival was held free of charge at the John M. Cuelenaere Library, the same venue this group used last year. Once again, the planning committee's aim was to create an accessible event that would get the whole community excited about reading with a particular focus on encouraging adults to help children develop a love of books.

The planning committee was overwhelmed by the number of people from the community who lined up outside the library to attend the event. After finally squeezing everyone in, the audience was treated to a slideshow demonstrating Brenda Clark's award-winning technique. In addition to hearing Brenda Clark read her favourite Franklin the Turtle tales aloud, Brenda Clark gave a special talk about the important work book illustrators do to bring a story to life through drawings. The audience also learned about how illustrations play an important role in reading.

After Brenda Clark's engaging presentation, the audience was treated to yet another special guest appearance – Franklin the Turtle! While the kids lined up for hugs, parents made their way over to the book table to pick out their favourite Franklin stories to read to their children later. And of course, Brenda Clark, who is always incredibly generous with her time, was on hand to personally sign books for each and every person who came out to the library.

Prior to the library event, Franklin also visited the local schools to promote reading and the event at the library. Franklin was also on hand to assist the Prince Albert Literacy Network in making a large donation of Franklin books to school libraries in the communities, making the stories of his adventures as accessible as possible to all his friends in the community.

The "For the Love of Reading" planning committee was delighted that the event was such a tremendous success. Thanks to their community reading festival, the programs and services that the Prince Albert Literacy Network offers has garnered more and more support from the community. To quote Brenda Lee, Chair of the "For the Love of Reading" planning committee, "Both events served to raise awareness of literacy and family literacy issues in the community. They also proved to be vehicles to inform the public about the purpose of Prince Albert Literacy Network. As well, many new families visited the library and learned of the free services and resources available. They were fun-filled afternoons for families and the focus was on books and reading!"

 
World Literacy of Canada 401 Richmond Street West, Studio 236 Toronto, Ontario M5V 3A8

Franklin Goes to the Hospital.

Paulette Bourgeois. Illustrated by Brenda Clark.
Toronto, ON: Kids Can Press, 1999.
32 p., pbk. & cl., $4.95 (pbk.), $12.95 (cl).
ISBN 1-55074-734-7 (pbk.), ISBN 1-55074-732-0 (cl.).

Subject Headings:
Hospitals-Juvenile fiction.
Surgery-Juvenile fiction.
Fear-Juvenile fiction.

***1/2 /4

Franklin's Class Trip.

excerpt:

Franklin could count by two and tie his shoes. He had gone with his class to the bakery, the fire station and the pet store. Today Franklin's class was going to the museum. Franklin was so excited that he could hardly eat his breakfast.
Franklin's enthusiasm about the class trip to the museum suddenly wanes, however, when Beaver reveals at the museum's entrance, "There are real dinosaurs inside." While Beaver knows he means just bones, Franklin interprets Beaver's words literally and is afraid that a ferocious, possibly turtle-eating dinosaur will be just around the next corner. For portions of the museum visit, Franklin loses himself in activities such as dressing up in armor in the medieval room or pretending to be an archaeologist. When it is finally time to visit the dinosaur exhibit though, Franklin tries to beg off, claiming he is tired. Mr. Owl insists Franklin continue, and he reluctantly and fearfully does so, only to be abruptly confronted by the toothed maw of a Tyrannosaurus. When Franklin discovers the exhibit holds only the real bones of once real dinosaurs, he relaxes and even shows his own ability to use language figuratively.

      Like all of the Franklin books, the author(s) embed(s) young children's emotions in a familiar experience, thereby empowering them to acknowledge and perhaps deal with the emotions' existence.

Recommended.

Franklin's Baby Sister.

excerpt:

Franklin's parents had exciting news. They were going to have a baby in the spring.

Franklin jumped up and down. He had always wanted to be a big brother. He had even practised with Bear's little sister, Beatrice.

"I can make babies laugh, and I can burp them, too," said Franklin.

"You will be a wonderful big brother," said his mother.

When Franklin learns that his mother is going to have a baby in the spring and he will acquire the title of "big brother," he cannot wait for that season to arrive. However, with the time frame of the very young, he expects spring and, therefore, the birth to occur momentarily and not at some distant future point. Again experiencing difficulties with others' figurative use of the English language, Franklin literally looks for spring "just around the next corner." Told that "April showers bring May flowers" and knowing that these two months are connected with spring, Franklin is ecstatic when his mother tells him that "they were having a shower that weekend." On Sunday, he puts on his rain gear only to encounter not raindrops but the shower of gifts for his yet unborn sibling. Finally the baby arrives, and Franklin gets to go the hospital where he successfully suggests a name for his new baby sister and "cradle[s] her gently in his arms."

      Undoubtedly parents awaiting the arrival of their next child may want to share Franklin's experience with their own young and possibly equally impatient children.

Recommended.

Franklin Goes to the Hospital.

excerpt:

Franklin sometimes had colds and tummy aches, and every now and then he got cuts and bruises. He went to the doctor's for regular checkups, and once the doctor came to Franklin's house. But until now, Franklin had never been to the hospital.
Well, that last statement is not absolutely true, for Franklin had been to the hospital when his sister, Harriet, was born. But perhaps I, like Franklin, am just being too literal, or it could be that the story's author is not intimately familiar with Bourgeois' corpus of "Franklin" books.

      Franklin Goes to the Hospital is one of those books that cataloguing professors loved to put on final exams for its cover resembles the typical "Franklin" book, prominently identifying Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark as the book's creators. From past experiences with their collaborations, one could conclude that Bourgeois is again the author and Clark the illustrator. However, the title page, the cataloger's "authority," immediately corrects such an inference by announcing that the "Story [is] based on characters created by Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark" though it is illustrated by Brenda Clark. The copyright page muddies the illustration attribution by saying that "Interior illustrations [were] prepared with the assistance of Shelley Southern." The same page also adds "Story written by Sharon Jennings." CIP data assigned main entry under title.

      While playing soccer, Franklin is hit in the chest with the ball, and that night he experiences pain while drying off following his bath. The next day his mother takes him to the doctor who concludes that Franklin's shell is cracked and that he will need to be operated on in hospital so that a pin can be inserted. While sharing the news of his impending operation with his friends, Franklin attempts to maintain a brave front, but inside he is quite afraid of the unknown awaiting him. Franklin's fearless facade crumbles when he is taken for x-rays because he thinks the x-rays will also reveal his fears. The doctor reassures Franklin, saying, "But just because you are afraid doesn't mean you aren't brave. Being brave mean doing what you have to do, no matter how scared you feel."

      While the storyline gives young children "permission" to have fears about having to go into hospital, the detailed illustrations of the hospital and the accompanying text give parents and children much to talk about as the book follows the processes typically followed in admitting patients to hospital, settling them into their rooms and prepping them for surgery. A book best read and discussed well before life's events require a real hospital visit.

Recommended.

Dave Jenkinson teaches courses in children's and young adult literature in the Faculty of Education, the University of Manitoba.

FOR THE LOVE OF READING 2


Brenda Clark and Franklin

The second annual For the Love of Reading event took place on Saturday, October 18, 2003, at John M. Cuelenaere Public Library in Prince Albert. Over 350 people took part in the event featuring renowned children’s illustrator and creator of Franklin the turtle, Brenda Clark. Brenda gave an excellent slide presentation explaining the work of an illustrator and the important role of illustrations when reading books. Following the presentation, excited children received hugs from “Franklin”, purchased Franklin books and had them signed by Brenda Clark, enjoyed a snack and listened to Franklin stories.

This event was part of World Literacy of Canada’s Kama Coast to Coast Community Reading Festivals project (http://www.worldlit.ca/kama_coast.html) which brings authors and illustrators to communities across Canada. This year, 18 reading festivals are taking place across Canada. Prince Albert is the only location in Saskatchewan. The purpose of the event is to raise community awareness and to promote reading as a fun and valuable activity.

Prior to the event, “Franklin” visited local schools promoting reading and the event as well as presenting Franklin books to school libraries. These books were presented in memory of Duwayne Barnett — a retired teacher who loved reading and promoting reading with her students.

In addition to the support received from World Literacy of Canada, For the Love of Reading was sponsored by the National Literacy Secretariat, SaskTel, Venturoso Books, Prince Albert Literacy Network and John M. Cuelenaere Public Library. Hillcrest Inn Bed and Breakfast generously donated a night’s accommodation for Brenda Clark.

Plans are underway for For the Love of Reading 3. To become involved in this, or other local literacy activities, contact the Prince Albert Literacy Network at 922-6736.

Dinosaur Junction Series (Video). Please refer to the title: Fight.



Does AIDS Hurt?: Educating Young Children About AIDS (Print-Non-Fiction). Quackenbush, Marcia and Villarreal, Sylvia. Network Publications (LRDC), 1988. 149 p. Order no. 8299 ($21.20 pbk.).

This practical resource, written by authors sensitive to the developmental needs of young children, emphasizes the use of age-appropriate responses to children's questions. Classroom examples demonstrate effective ways to provide relevant and appropriate AIDS education to young students. The topics covered include:

  • when to bring up the subject of AIDS
  • what possible problems might arise when discussing AIDS with young children
  • what one might do when a child, family, or friends are at risk for or infected with HIV
  • how one might deal with HIV infected students or staff
  • how to stay updated on AIDS information.

Included are a table of contents, a bibliography, and a list of American information sources.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Grade 4; Grade 5; A Healthy Body; Teacher Reference



A Dog, Three Cats and Table Manners (Video). National Film Board of Canada (MGR), 1974. 25 min. Dup. order no. V9015.

(CAN) This compilation of three humourous animated short stories includes Every Dog's Guide to the Playground that communicates important safety tips and creates a springboard for discussion of sport and playground dangers.

The second program is The Dingles, a charming story of Doris Dingle and her three cats that are threatened by an unexpected gale.

Lastly, it includes Lady Fishbourne's Complete Guide to Better Table Manners that features four dinner guests of curious demeanour that commit unforgivable acts at the table but are redeemed thanks to Lady Fishbourne's book of eating etiquette.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Grade 4; Grade 5; Safety; Social Relationships



Feelings Series (Print-Non-Fiction). Please refer to the titles: Afraid, Angry, Hurt, Jealous, Lonely, and Sad.



The Fight (Video). (Dinosaur Junction Series). Magic Lantern Communications Ltd. (MGR), 1993. 11 min. Dup. order no. V9535.

After a wheeliboard accident, Stoney and Bronto learn the hard way that disagreements can easily escalate into a destructive cycle of name calling and one-upmanship. When they turn to a trusted adult for advice, they also learn that turning a physical fight into a test of skill lets everyone become a winner.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Social Relationships



Fighting Germs and Diseases (Video). (Head to Toe Series). Agency for Instructional Technology (MGR), 1993. 15 min. Dup. order no. V9376. Teacher's Guide for series - Order no. G9367 ($8.00 pbk.).

This video tells how germs cause disease. It also discusses health care workers, institutions that deal with disease, immunization, and disease prevention. The Head to Toe Series stresses the prevention of risky health behaviours and assists young students with knowledge, attitudes, and practices in the health and life sciences areas. Supporting print is available for the series.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; A Healthy Body



Finders Keepers for Franklin (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette and Clark, Brenda, illus. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1997. unp. Order no. 8510 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) The infamous Franklin experiences internal turmoil after he finds a camera and must decide whether he should keep it or try to locate the rightful owner. As usual, Brenda Clark's colourful illustrations are delightful.
Suggested Use: Grade 2; Grade 3; Decision-making Process; Social Relationships
Other Use: English Language Arts: Elementary Level; Kindergarten



First Aid Basics (Print-Non-Fiction). Canadian Red Cross Society, The (CRC), 1995. 50 p. ISBN 1-55104-107-3 ($1.50 pbk.). assists

(CAN) This pocket-sized guide provides useful information on various aspects of first aid such as emergency action principles, treatment for various conditions, what to include in a first aid kit, and instructions on calling for emergency medical assistance. It is intended to be used as a reference book to familiarize readers with first aid procedures before they are needed or as a quick source of information in an emergency. It, of course, is not a substitute for taking a first aid course. Included is a table of contents.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Grade 4; Grade 5; Safety; Teacher Reference



Franklin Fibs (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1991. unp. Order no. 8512 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) In Franklin Fibs the turtle boasts about his ability to eat 76 flies in the blink of an eye. When Franklin shares his problem with his parents, they allow the young turtle to find his own solution to the dilemma. Franklin's embarrassment and regret over his fib are well presented. The illustrations by Brenda Clark are exceptional. Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Decision-making Process; Social Relationships
Other Use: English Language Arts: Elementary Level



Franklin Goes to School (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette and Clark, Brenda, illus. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1995. unp. Order no. 8513 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) Franklin is very nervous about going to school. However, his wise teacher, Mr. Owl, manages to alleviate his fear and guide his learning so that Franklin has a most enjoyable first day at school. The illustrations by Brenda Clark are delightful .
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Self-esteem; Social Relationships



Franklin in the Dark (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1986. unp. Order no. 8803 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) This book describes the famous turtle's fear of the dark. When Franklin travels in search of a cure for his phobia, he discovers that everyone, even his mother, is afraid of something. Franklin solves the problem himself—with a night light! As usual, Brenda Clark's colourful illustrations are delightful.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Self-esteem; Social Relationships



Franklin Is Bossy (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1993. unp. Order no. 8506 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) After Franklin's friends proclaim that they don't want to play with him because he is bossy, he learns that friendship often entails consideration for others, sacrifice, and compromise. Brenda Clark's colourful illustrations are a pleasure to view.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Social Relationships



Franklin Is Messy (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1994. unp. Order no. 8507 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) Franklin, the endearing turtle, suffers the consequences of having a messy room when he loses a special sword that he needs to play Knights in Armour with his friends. When he cleans up his room, he finds enough material to make a new sword and a shield too! He then dubs himself "Sir Franklin, Loyal and Brave and Neat." Brenda Clark's colourful illustrations are delightful.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Self-esteem; Social Relationships
Other Use: English Language Arts: Elementary Level; Kindergarten



Franklin Rides a Bike (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette and Clark, Brenda, illus. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1997. unp. Order no. 8509 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) Franklin is really depressed because he cannot seem to ride his bike without training wheels. His friends are successful, but he just wibbles and wobbles and teeters and totters and finally falls. Then, after a frank discussion with his mother , he reflects upon the fact that everybody struggles in some areas of their lives and comes to the conclusion that if you really want to learn something you must never give up trying! Brenda Clark's cheery illustrations are outstanding.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Self-esteem; Social Relationships
Other Use: Physical Education: Elementary Level



Franklin's Blanket (Print-Fiction). Bourgeois, Paulette. Kids Can Press (LRDC), 1995. unp. Order no. 8508 ($3.45 pbk.).

(CAN) Franklin is extremely upset when he loses his favourite, blue, baby blanket. Eventually, he remembers that he used the blanket to hide the brussel sprouts that he didn't want to eat for supper. Brenda Clark's colourful illustrations are exceptional.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Self-esteem; Social Relationships
Other Use: English Language Arts: Elementary Level; Kindergarten



Fresh Air (Video). (Head to Toe Series). Agency for Instructional Technology (MGR), 1993. 15 min. Dup. order no. V9374. Teacher's Guide for series - Order no. G9367 ($8.00 pbk.).

This video shows how the body breathes, and discusses asthma, and other respiratory problems. It also addresses protecting the respiratory system by avoiding pollutants. The Head to Toe Series stresses the prevention of risky health behaviours and assists young students with knowledge, attitudes, and practices in the health and life sciences areas. Supporting print is available for the series.
Suggested Use: Grade 2; A Healthy Body



From Crime (Print-Non-Fiction). Carter, K. (Safety Series). Rourke Pubns., Inc. (LRDC), 1994. 24 p. Order no. 8514 ($14.85 hdc.).

Interspersed with colour photographs, this American book defines crime and offers suggestions for young children to protect themselves and others from danger. Included are a table of contents, a glossary, and an index.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; Grade 3; Safety



Fueling Up (Video). (Head to Toe Series). Agency for Instructional Technology (MGR), 1993. 15 min. Dup. order no. V9372. Teacher's Guide for series - Order no. G9367 ($8.00 pbk.).

This video shows how the body breaks food down and uses it for fuel. It also promotes eating well for good nutrition. The Head to Toe Series stresses the prevention of risky health behaviours and assists young students with knowledge, attitudes, and practices in the health and life sciences areas. Supporting print is available for the series.
Suggested Use: Grade 1; Grade 2; A Healthy Body

HOMETOWN: Ovett
HIGH SCHOOL: Sand Hill
COLLEGE: Jones County Junior College
ACTIVITIES: I am married and the mother of three (17, 4 and almost 2). I am going back to school to acquire a nursing degree. My four-year-old son is autistic, and I want to work in my community to help autistic children and their families in coping and dealing with autism.

The Best Gift I Ever Received
"Luz You"

The best gift I ever received was not a material gift but rather a gift of hope. The day was October 17, 2001. I was getting my son Mason out of the bathtub and into his pajamas. He fought with me as he always did as I dressed him. When I was through, I hugged him and said, love you. To my surprise, he responded "luz you". I was totally shocked and said to him again, "love you". Again he responded "luz you". The tears began to roll down my face and I ran to tell my husband all about the encounter. We laughed and rejoiced because our son had finally said two words together.

I called my parents, brother and friends to let them know that my son had finally said these two special words. I am sure that this kind of response is normal for any parent whose child just said his first two words, but in our case it was a sign of hope. Mason had just had his third birthday the month before and his speech had still not properly developed. At that time he had been in speech therapy for six months with little progress. These two words being said together not only had special meaning but encouraged us that maybe his speech would develop.

Mason was diagnosed developmentally delayed in February 2002 and began school in the special education department at the county school. He made very little progress. Neither his speech nor his behavior was getting any better. We continued to take him to school as well as get him outside speech therapy. Every time I would get frustrated and discouraged, I would remember the night I heard his words "luz you" and then I would get my second wind and work on a new plan that would help him.

In January 2003, Mason was diagnosed with severe autism. I knew this in my heart way before the specialist told me. I spent most of the next week crying and mourning this news. A parent wants so much for their child and in a matter of a couple of hours it seemed to have all vanished. I knew my son was special. I just did not understand how special.

I sometimes find myself frustrated and angry as to why my son. I wonder why he has this disease and why I as a parent have to fight so hard to get him the help he needs. Then it came to me. God sent me this child because he knows how strong I am. He knows that I will help him as well as other children with special needs. There are many nights that I find myself physically aching from handling Mason. When I get this way or really frustrated in my dealing with his autism, I remember two words "luz you," and I smile and know that I have hope for him.

 
 
 Education Services Foundation 2600 Lakeland Terrace Jackson MS 39216 1.800.986.4322

World Literacy of Canada

Kids' Kama
Brenda Clark Inspires Young Illustrators

Brenda Clark, illustrator of the Franklin the Turtle series, visited Rose Avenue Junior Public School on February 28, 2003 on behalf of World Literacy of Canada. Clark demonstrated her award-winning technique to two groups of 150 enthusiastic young illustrators and Franklin fans in grades four to six. Brenda amazed the young fans by showing the illustrations she did as a little girl along with her original sketches of Franklin.  
Brenda Clark captivates students with her slideshow and storytelling.
Brenda showed that through hard work and practice, she was able to develop her illustrating skills and talent to create the image that is now known as Franklin. As Gabilan, a grade five student, explained, "Brenda taught us that it doesn’t matter whether you are good at drawing or not. If you use your imagination and have lots of patience, you can become a very good artist."
   
Throughout the day, the costumed Franklin roamed the halls of the school visiting the kindergarten classes. It was hard to contain the excitement of these four and five year-olds as they got their first glimpse of Franklin after having just heard their favorite Franklin story from a special guest reader. Franklin is so popular in the school that Mary Lou Roder, the librarian, has to limit the number of Franklin books each child can sign out of the library.

Mr. Zommers, WLC supporter and guest reader, delights young Franklin fans with their favourite Franklin story.
   

Many students in this multicultural school, where English is often their second language, relate to Franklin who crosses language and cultural boundaries. Picture books are very helpful for many of these students who are learning to read. "I like Franklin because of the wonderful illustrations. If I did not know how to read or if I did not understand properly what I was reading, I could look at the pictures and guess what is happening in the story," explained Sivaniya, a grade six student.

 

 

 

 
This event is part of World Literacy of Canada’s Kids' Kama program, which was designed to encourage an early love of reading. Rose Avenue Junior Public School is located in the heart of St. James Town, one of the most multicultural and densely populated communities in Canada. There are 960 students from kindergarten to grade six in the school. World Literacy of Canada has a special relationship with this school and hopes to continue to work with the school to encourage and support family literacy. A storytelling festival has been organized in partnership with Rose Avenue that will involve the whole community of St. James Town. For more information or to get involved with this community project, see the St. James Town Storytelling Festival.
   

 

 

World Literacy of Canada 401 Richmond Street West, Studio 236 Toronto, Ontario M5V 3A8
Tel. (416) 977-0008 Fax. (416) 977-1112 Email: info@worldlit.ca

Journal of the Senate

________________

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1999

The Senate was called to order by the President.

Devotional Exercises

Devotional exercises were conducted by the Reverend Albert P. Collins of Websterville.

Message from the House

    A message was received from the House of Representatives by Mr. Bertrand, its Second Assistant Clerk, as follows:

Mr. President:

I am directed to inform the Senate the House has adopted Joint Resolutions of the following titles:

J.R.H. 30. Joint resolution in memory of former Representative Lyle K. Rice of Rutland City.

J.R.H. 31. Joint resolution congratulating Marshall, Minor and Brenda Clark on their being awarded the Vermont Grocer's Associations's 1998 "Grocer of the Year Award".

In the adoption of which the concurrence of the Senate is requested.

Committee Bill Introduced; Rules Suspended; Bill Committed

Senate committee bill of the following title was introduced, read the first time, and, under the rule, placed on the Calendar for notice tomorrow:

By the Committee on Agriculture,

S. 81. An act relating to agricultural education and public information.

Thereupon, pending entry of the bill on the Calendar for notice tomorrow, on motion of Senator Kittell, the rules were suspended and the bill was taken up for immediate consideration.

    Thereupon, pending second reading of the bill, on motion of Senator Kittell, the bill was committed to the Committee on Education.

Bill Introduced

Senate bill of the following title was introduced, read the first time and referred:

By Senator Bahre,

S. 82. An act relating to county review of SRS decisions that affect parental rights.

To the Committee on Health and Welfare.

Joint Resolutions Placed on Calendar

Joint resolution originating in the House of the following title was read the first time and is as follows:

    J.R.H. 30. Joint resolution in memory of former Representative Lyle K. Rice of Rutland City.

Whereas, Lyle Rice was born in the Town of Holland and spent his formative years in the Northeast Kingdom where he graduated from Orleans High School, and

Whereas, he later moved south to Rutland County where he was employed at Railway Express and later, for 34 years, by the United States Postal Service, from which he retired as a postal supervisor, and

Whereas, after concluding over three decades as a federal public servant, Lyle Rice turned his attention to electoral politics, when in 1965, he won a seat in the Vermont House of Representatives, as one of the new members from Rutland City, and

Whereas, his constituents were so pleased with the manner in which he performed his representational duties that his tenure in the House ultimately totaled 19 years, and

Whereas, over the course of his legislative career, Lyle Rice served on several committees, including Natural Resources, Municipal Corporations, and Government Operations of which he was also a Vice Chair, and

Whereas, his familiarity with the legislative process and the esteem he had earned from his colleagues resulted in his selection, in 1983, as a member of the House Rules Committee, and

Whereas, aside from his professional and legislative activities, he was a long-time member of the Masons and an amateur railroad historian, now therefore be it

RESOLVED BY THE SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES:

That the members of the General Assembly were saddened to learn of the passing of their long-time colleague, former Representative Lyle Rice, and be it further

RESOLVED: That the Secretary of State be directed to send a copy of this resolution to his widow, Lillian Rice in Pittsford, and to his sister, Olive Gardner in Newport.

Thereupon, in the discretion of the Chair, under Rule 51, the joint resolution was placed on the Calendar for action tomorrow.

Joint resolution originating in the House of the following title was read the first time and is as follows:

    J.R.H. 31. Joint resolution congratulating Marshall, Minor and Brenda Clark on their being awarded the Vermont Grocer's Association's 1998 "Grocer of the Year Award".

Whereas, the Clark family has a long history in the retail grocery business, beginning in 1927 when Minor Clark operated a store in East Arlington, Vermont, and

Whereas, the store became affiliated with the Independent Grocers Alliance in 1931, and

Whereas, Ray and Ardis Clark left the family store in 1959 to purchase the Spofford IGA, and

Whereas, the Clark's IGA stores have been serving the people of Ludlow and Londonderry for 35 years, beginning with Ludlow in 1964 and Londonderry in 1974, and

Whereas, Ray and Ardis Clark retired in 1989, passing the business to the third generation, Marshall, Minor and Brenda Clark, and

Whereas, the stores have been expanded and renovated to better serve the growing Ludlow and Londonderry communities, and

Whereas, the Clark family and employees have contributed to the welfare and betterment of their community as a major part of the Clarks' way of doing business, including generous supporters of community events and charitable fundraisers such as Little League, MS ski races, Vermont Grocers' Scholarship Program, Special Olympics, Londonderry Center, and American Cancer Society, and

Whereas, the Clark family was chosen "Grocers of the Year" for 1998, now therefore be it

RESOLVED BY THE SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES:

    That the General Assembly congratulates Marshall, Minor and Brenda Clark, owners of Clark's IGA's in Ludlow and Londonderry, on their being awarded the Vermont Grocers' Association 1998, "Grocer of the Year Award," and be it further

RESOLVED: That the Secretary of State be directed to send a copy of this resolution to Marshall, Minor and Brenda Clark of Londonderry and Ludlow.

Thereupon, in the discretion of the Chair, under Rule 51, the joint resolution was placed on the Calendar for action tomorrow.

Committee Relieved of Further Consideration; Bill Committed

On motion of Senator Chard, the Committee on Education was relieved of further consideration of Senate bill entitled:

S. 40. An act to relate student count to the portion of school district budget which comes from public sources.

Thereupon, pending entry of the bill on the Calendar for notice tomorrow, on motion of Senator Chard, the bill was committed to the Committee on Finance.

Appointment of Senate Member to Vermont State Nuclear Advisory

Panel (V-SNAP)

Pursuant to the provisions of 18 V.S.A. _1700, the President, on behalf of the Committee on Committees, announced the appointment of the following Senator to serve on the Vermont State Nuclear Advisory Panel (V-SNAP) for a term of two (2) years ending on January 15, 2001:

Senator Shumlin

Adjournment

On motion of Senator Shumlin, the Senate adjourned until eleven o_clock and thirty minutes in the morning.

Summer 2003 edition Changemakers

In Overbrook, a change agent

Congratulations to Brenda Clark, the Notebook's West Region Changemaker for Schools!

larger photo

Photo: Harvey Finkle

Brenda Clark

Clark is a classroom assistant at Overbrook Education Center (OEC) in a fifth grade classroom serving visually impaired and blind children. In 1995, she started the first Special Olympics basketball team at OEC, the District's school for visually impaired students in grades K-8.

In its first year, the OEC Special Olympics basketball team won a bronze medal at the Philadelphia Special Olympics March Games. Then and now, Clark says, OEC has the only team in Pennsylvania with visually impaired children.

The Special Olympics basketball team spurred the creation of multiple sports teams at OEC, including volleyball, soccer, and track, which involved both visually impaired and non-visually impaired children. The teams competed against other schools in Philadelphia, and Clark coached every one of them, along with Tina Randall, a teacher at OEC.

For Clark, coaching sports is not just about teaching children how to win the game. "It all centered around giving something to the vision-impaired students here, so that they could have self-esteem and participate in a sport," she says. "They learned how to work together."

Working under the motto that "exercise to the body will bring exercise to the mind," Clark also sees the positive impact that participating in sports has on students' behavior and academic performance.

This spring, four students who have participated in OEC's Special Olympics program since it began in 1995 will graduate from high school, three of them with offers to attend college.

Clark's connections with the students she coaches spill over into many arenas off the court. She has taught the visually impaired children how to use public transportation to get to practice, often riding the route with them at first. She started a newsletter about OEC's sports teams, training students to interview, photograph, and write stories about each other. She is a mentor to one of her former Special Olympics athletes.

Clark's pride for these students runs deep. "[The children] have really taught me patience, and tolerance, and a lot of gratitude," she remarks.

For Clark, coaching Special Olympics is the right way to give back to her community. She encourages others to find a way to give back that is right for them. "None of us are here today, if it wasn't for somebody to push us along the way. So help pay it forward, and help someone else."

SHERIDAN FÊTES ITS
PREMIER'S AWARD NOMINEES

For immediate release: February 8, 1999

OAKVILLE, ONTARIO - On Wednesday evening, February 10, Sheridan College will celebrate its 1998 Premier's Award nominees with a formal reception and dinner, topped off by a special production of "Kiss Me Kate" at Theatre Sheridan.

"The Sheridan community is delighted to have an opportunity to welcome its graduates 'home' and to celebrate their achievements," said Sheridan's President Sheldon Levy. The nominees, all exceptional individuals who have gone on to remarkable careers since leaving Sheridan, are Karen Bridgman-Acker, Mark McKenney, Brenda Clark, Bill Paul, and Dr. Catherine Henderson. When the Premier's Awards are presented next Monday, February 15 at the annual conference of the Association of Colleges of Applied Arts & Technology of Ontario in downtown Toronto, one of the recipients will be Karen Bridgman-Acker, a 1986 graduate of Sheridan's Social Service Worker Program and Sheridan's nominee in the Health Sciences category. Karen was nominated, and selected to receive an award, for her outstanding career achievements coupled with her extraordinary community involvement. Currently a Social Worker with the Hamilton Children's Aid Society and a part-time faculty member at Sheridan, Karen has worked tirelessly for the past thirteen years to help women and children in Hamilton and Halton.

Mark McKenney, Sheridan's nominee in Technology and a 1974 Chemical Engineering graduate, is a pioneer in the field of environmental technology. When he began his career with the Ontario Ministry of the Environment (MOE) the concept of environmental protection was not widely understood. Mark's achievements include the creation of an Investigation & Enforcement Branch in the MOE, and the launch of the Blue Box curbside recycling program. Today, Mark is President of the Canadian Environmental Industry Association - Ontario, and an international consultant.

Brenda Clark, a 1977 Illustration grad and Applied Arts nominee, is well known to young children and their parents for her creation, Franklin the Turtle. Written by Paulette Bourgeois and illustrated by Clark, the Franklin series has achieved worldwide success with millions in book sales and a rapidly growing industry in merchandising and television programming. Together, Brenda Clark and Paulette Bourgeois encourage Franklin's participation in community events and charitable activities, and Clark herself shares her time and efforts to help raise awareness and funds in support of children's issues such as literacy and health.

Bill Paul, Sheridan's Business nominee and a 1981 graduate of the Business Administration Marketing program, is well known in golf circles for his affable style and dedication to promoting the Canadian golf scene. As Managing Director of Championships for the Royal

Canadian Golf Association, it's Bill who oversees all facets of sales, operations, and player recruitment for seven national amateur championships and two professional championships: the Canadian Open and Senior Open.

Dr. Catherine Henderson is a joint nominee (by Sheridan and Centennial College) for the Honorary Premier's Award, the winner of which will be announced at the Premier's Awards ceremony next Monday. Dr. Henderson is the President of the Ontario College of Art and Design, past President of Centennial College, and the first-ever community college graduate to attain a college presidency. She graduated from Sheridan's Early Childhood Education program in 1977 and joined the college as a part-time instructor, then moved through the Sheridan ranks to become Vice President Academic in 1990. Dr. Henderson is renowned for her leadership and teamwork, educational expertise, and insight into future trends.

The Premier's Awards were instituted in 1992 to recognize outstanding achievements by community college graduates. Four awards are conferred annually, one each in the following areas of study: applied arts, business, health sciences and technology. Winners are presented with a Premier's Award Medal and have the opportunity to direct a five-thousand dollar bursary to the college of their choice. Past Sheridan winners include Steve Williams (Applied Arts - 1997) and Linda Lundstrom (Applied Arts - 1993).

Caring from the Heart

 

Big Sister Nancy Meister Doty and Little Sister Brenda Clark

 

           

(From left) Nancy and Brenda in 1970 - just 7 months after they were matched; at Nancy's wedding in 1974; and with BBBS Executive Director Ed Hagan at the BBBS Centennial Dinner in 2004

I first met my Big Sister on June 3, 1970.  My grandmother Shirley took my three older sisters and me to her church that evening to meet our own Big Sisters. The church basement was decorated like a big birthday party.  This had extra special meaning for me because it really was my birthday.  It was my sixth birthday and one that I'll always remember.

           

The room was filled with lots of woman and excited young girls like me.  I still recall the ice cream sundae that I ate with my new Big Sister Nancy.  She told me how extra special I was at the table because it was my birthday.

           

What I didn't know then was that I would still have my Big Sister in my life thirty-three years later to share things with and grow old together.

           

I was born the youngest of four girls and was being raised by a single father.   My parents were divorced at a young age.  When I met my Big Sister, I was too young to realize what having a Big Sister really meant.

           

My older sisters were then eleven, ten, and eight.  Their relationships with their Big Sisters did not last as long as mine, but this was due to various life events.  Some matches evolve with marriage, family, and career changes, and others do not.  Either way, the impact that a Big Sister makes can last years even a lifetime.

           

My match with Nancy opened a new world for me.  She introduced me to her family and showed me what true family values were.   I still fondly refer to her parents as Aunt Lill and Uncle Joe.  We shared many great conversations on trips to visit them, and we would attend church on Sunday.  Nancy adored me, and she always let me know she was there for me.

           

When I was ten, Nancy enrolled me in charm school.  There I learned proper manners and how to carry myself as a young lady.  Nancy knew what I needed, and I always admired and aspired to be like her.

           

Nancy's husband to be, Art Doty, took my charm school graduation photo.  That photo represents my transition from a tomboy to a little lady and makes me smile every time I see it.

           

Even after her marriage, Nancy continued to make me a part of her life. She was essential to my growth as a teenager when I was learning about independence and responsibility.

           

Her own career was inspiring to me because she worked hard but had always taken a few hours a week to spend with me, even if it was just a trip to McDonald's or a movie at home.  She had taken me to work with her on career day. Now they call it Bring Your Daughter to Work Day, but I'd much prefer Bring Your Little Sister (or Brother) to Work Day!

           

It was very reassuring to know that Nancy would never give up on me.  I was included in her family vacations and was always excited to go camping and skiing.

           

My father was not always able to afford vacations, but he was always thankful for my Big Sister and for her involvement with me.  My father, Nancy and Art are good friends.  My father and Nancy are the two most important people in my life.

           

At the age of eighteen, I moved to Florida.  There were sometimes long periods of time when we didn't always call or write, but whenever we did, it was so easy to catch up on lost time.  In my mind and in my heart, Nancy has always cared about me and given me advice when asked.

           

Every visit to Michigan always included a visit from Nancy and Art.  It was always a special vacation from Florida when I could also visit with Aunt Lill and Uncle Joe.  I still have the pink elephant piggy bank that they bought for me at the Detroit Zoo when I was a little girl.  Her parents are elderly now, and time I get to visit with them is even more important with each passing year.  

           

My life has been forever changed as a result of my relationship and match with this wonderful lady.  She always remembers my birthday and brings a smile to my face with her Valentine, Halloween, and Christmas card greetings and packages.  She's been my role model and helped me become the woman that I am today.

           

I now live in San Francisco where I am a successful, single, career woman.  I have been working in the hospital industry for the last fifteen years and now work for one of the top ten hospitals in the country.  My career and profession are very important achievements in my life, but I feel I am the confident and strong person I am today because of my Big Sister.

           

As a tribute to Nancy, I've recently applied to the local chapter in San Francisco to become a Big Sister.  I know there is a young girl who will benefit from all that I have learned about the bond of friendship and true caring from the heart.

                                                                         By Brenda Clark

 

This story, from a Lansing match, was included in the BBBS Centennial book "Little Moments Big Magic".  Click here for more information or to order this book full of heartwarming stories.

Franklin Goes to the Hospital (Franklin)

Our price: $4.99
Authors: Sharon Jennings, Brenda Clark, Paulette Bourgeois, and Shelley Southern
Published: 01 March, 2000
Publisher: Scholastic
Media Type: Paperback
Availability: Usually ships in 24 hours
ISBN: 0439083702
Sales Rank: 95857

Amazon.com prices subject to change.
Customer ReviewsAverage customer rating:
Wonderful!
This book was great for preparing my daughter for an upcoming surgery. It went through the basics of what she would experience, even if the reason for the surgery was different, and it was done with a character she was already familiar with. The day of her surgery she was telling me what would happen next.
It's Ok
This shows that it's ok to be scared at the hospital. Franklin got hit in the chest at a soccer game. He ends up having to go to the hospital. He thinks that when you take a x-ray. Everyone will see how scare you are inside. Franklin didn't want everyone to know how scared he was. This a good book for any child that has to go to the hospital. I t shows you don't have to be scared. The doctors and nurses are there to help you.
A Must-Have If Your Child Is Having an Operation
I purchased Franklin Goes to The Hospital for my 5 year old son, who was having abdominal surgery last week. He loved the book so much, that he read it every night until the surgery. It really explained all of the different procedures involved in going to the hospital - on a level that he could understand! I strongly recommend this book to any parent who is faced with having to explain surgery to a small child!

MARC History
The Michigan Antique Radio Club (MARC) was officially founded October 19, 1985 at the Dillon Inn (now the Hampton Inn) in Lansing, Michigan. Present at this historical meeting to found MARC was Jim and Brenda Clark, Larry Anderson, Karl Rommel, Mike Male, Dick Perry and John Kent.
Jim Clark, Brenda Clark, Larry Anderson, Karl Rommel, Mike Male, Dick Perry

Prior to there being an official club, Jim and Brenda Clark sponsored and organized four (4) swap meets in the name of the Michigan Antique Radio Club...the very first one being held May 5, 1984 at the Marshall Street Armory in Lansing, MI. The next two (2) swap meets were held at the same location on October 13, 1984 and April 20, 1985. The fourth swap meet was held September 21, 1985 at the Dillon Inn. After the club was officially founded, the first swap meet was held January 25, 1986 at the President's Inn in Grand Rapids, MI and was hosted by Larry Anderson.

In the years since its founding of the club membership has grown to nearly 900. While most MARC members live within the Great Lakes region of the U.S. the organization also is represented throughout this country as well as Canada, Europe and Australia. The organization holds three one day swap meets with programming and competitive display presentations as well as a two day convention meet, EXTRAVAGANZA, held in Lansing, Michigan each July. MARC also publishes "The Michigan Antique Radio Chronicle," which is included with membership.

Issued by THE LABOR AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COMMISSION

 

FINAL AWARD DENYING COMPENSATION

(Affirming Award and Decision of Administrative Law Judge)

 

Injury No.: 01-100511

Employee: Kevin Clark (Deceased)

 

Dependents: Brenda Clark, widow; Brittany and Candis

Clark, minor children

 

Employer: Hussmann Corporation

 

Insurer: Pacific Employers Insurance Company

 

Date of Accident: June 4, 2001

 

Place and County of Accident: St. Louis County, Missouri

 

The above‑entitled workers' compensation case is submitted to the Labor and Industrial Relations Commission for review as provided by section 287.480 RSMo. Having reviewed the evidence and considered the whole record, the Commission finds that the award of the administrative law judge is supported by competent and substantial evidence and was made in accordance with the Missouri Workers' Compensation Act. Pursuant to section 286.090 RSMo, the Commission affirms the award and decision of the administrative law judge dated November 5, 2003, and awards no compensation in the above‑captioned case.

 

The award and decision of Administrative Law Judge John Howard Percy, issued November 5, 2003, is attached and incorporated by this reference.

 

Given at Jefferson City, State of Missouri, this 30th day of March 2004.

 

LABOR AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COMMISSION

 

 

Patrick Deaton, Acting Chairman

 

 

Ken Legan, Member

 

 

Attest: John J. Hickey, Member

 

 

Secretary

 

AWARD

 

 

Employee: Kevin Clark (Deceased) Injury No.: 01-100511

 

Dependents: Brenda Clark, widow; and Brittany and Candis Before the

Clark, minor children Division of Workers

Employer: Hussmann Corporation Compensation

Department of Labor and Industrial

Additional Party: None Relations of Missouri

Jefferson City, Missouri

Insurer: Pacific Employers Insurance Company

 

Hearing Date: July 25 and August 4, 2003 Checked by: JHP:tr

 

 

FINDINGS OF FACT AND RULINGS OF LAW

 

1. Are any benefits awarded herein? No

 

2.            Was the injury or occupational disease compensable under Chapter 287? No

 

3. Was there an accident or incident of occupational disease under the Law? Yes

4.            Date of accident or onset of occupational disease: June 4, 2001

 

5.            State location where accident occurred or occupational disease was contracted: St. Louis County, Mo.

 

6. Was above employee in employ of above employer at time of alleged accident or occupational disease? Yes

7. Did employer receive proper notice? Yes

 

8. Did accident or occupational disease arise out of and in the course of the employment? No

9.            Was claim for compensation filed within time required by Law? Yes

 

10. Was employer insured by above insurer? Yes

 

11. Describe work employee was doing and how accident occurred or occupational disease contracted:

Employee was shot and killed while sitting in his automobile on employers parking lot shortly before the commencement of his shift.

 

12. Did accident or occupational disease cause death? Yes Date of death? June 4, 2001

13. Part(s) of body injured by accident or occupational disease: N/A

 

14.           Nature and extent of any permanent disability: None

 

15. Compensation paid to-date for temporary disability: None

 

16. Value necessary medical aid paid to date by employer/insurer? None
