FINDINGS OF FACT and RULINGS OF LAW:

 

 

Employee: Kevin Clark (Deceased) Injury No.: 01-100511

 

Dependents: Brenda Clark, widow; and Brittany and Candis Before the

Clark, minor children Division of Workers

Employer: Hussmann Corporation Compensation

Department of Labor and Industrial

Additional Party: None Relations of Missouri

Jefferson City, Missouri

 

Insurer: Pacific Employers Insurance Company Checked by: JHP

 

A hearing in this proceeding was held on July 25 and August 4, 2003. Both parties submitted excellent proposed awards, the latter of which was received on September 22, 2003.

 

STIPULATIONS

 

The parties stipulated that on or about June 4, 2001:

 

1. the employer and Kevin Clark were operating under and subject to the provisions of the Missouri Workers' Compensation Law;

2. the employer's liability was insured by Pacific Employers Insurance Company;

3. the employee's average weekly wage was $616.00;

4. the rate of death benefits was $410.67 per week; and

5. Mark Manzella shot and killed Kevin Clark, an employee of Hussmann Corporation, while employee was sitting in his automobile on the Hussmann Corporation parking lot in St. Louis County, Missouri, shortly before the commencement of employees 7:00 a.m. shift.

 

The parties further stipulated that:

 

1. the employer had notice of the death of employee and a claim for compensation was filed within the time prescribed by law;

2. employer/insurer have not paid any death benefits; and

3. employer/insurer have not paid any medical expenses or burial expenses.

 

ISSUES

 

The issues to be resolved in this proceeding are:

 

1. whether the death of employee arose out of and was in the course of his employment with Hussmann Corporation;

2. if the death of employee is a compensable event, who are the statutory dependents of Kevin Clark, hereinafter referred to as deceased employee; and

3. if the death of employee is a compensable event, what are the death benefits to which his dependents are entitled.

ARISING OUT OF AND IN THE COURSE OF EMPLOYMENT

 

The parties stipulated that Kevin Clark, deceased employee herein, was murdered by Mark Manzella while employee was sitting in his automobile on the Hussmann Corporation parking lot in St. Louis County, Missouri, shortly before the commencement of employees 7:00 a.m. shift.

 

Claimants are Brenda Clark, widow, and Brittany and Candis Clark, surviving minor children of Kevin Clark. They are claiming statutory death benefits as provided in Section 287.240 Mo. Rev. Stat. (2000).

 

Employer/insurer contend that claimants death did not arise out of his employment.[1]

 

A claimant must prove that his or her injuries resulted from an accident "arising out of and in the course of his employment". Section 287.120.1 Mo. Rev. Stat. (2000); Johnson v. Evans & Dixon, 861 S.W.2d 633 (Mo. App. 1993); Johnson v. City of Kirksville, 855 S.W.2d 396 (Mo. App. 1993); McClain v. Welsh Co., 748 S.W.2d 720 (Mo. App. 1988); Palmer v. H. E. Miller Oldsmobile, Inc., 731 S.W.2d 389 (Mo. App. 1987); Kunce v. Junge Baking Company, 432 S.W.2d 602 (Mo. App. 1968). The standard of proof is reasonable probability. Fischer v. Archdiocese of St. Louis, 793 S.W.2d 195, 199 (Mo. App. 1990); Banner Iron Works v. Mordis, 664 S.W.2d 770, 773 (Mo. App. 1983). "Probable means founded on reason and experience which inclines the mind to believe but leaves room to doubt." Tate v. Southwestern Bell Telephone Co., 715 S.W.2d 326, 329 (Mo. App. 1986); Fischer at 198.

 

Amendments made to Section 287.020 in 1993 have codified in part and modified in part prior caselaw concerning when an injury arises out of and in the course of employment. Subsection 2 of Section 287.020 provides that an injury is compensable if it is clearly work related and arises out of and in the course of employment. The Supreme Court held in Kasl v. Bristol Care, Inc., 984 S.W.2d 852 (Mo. 1999) that the foregoing language adopted the test enunciated in Wolfgeher v. Wagner Cartage Service, Inc., 646 S.W.2d 781 (Mo. 1983).

 

Subsection 3(2) of Section 287.020 provides that an injury arises out of and in the course of the employment "only if (a) It is reasonably apparent, upon consideration of all the circumstances, that the employment is a substantial factor in causing the injury, [2] and; (b) It can be seen to have followed as a natural incident of the work; and (c) It can be fairly traced to the employment as a proximate cause; and (d) It does not come from a hazard or risk unrelated to the employment to which workers would have been equally exposed outside of and unrelated to the employment in normal nonemployment life[.]"[3] In construing subsection (2)(d) the Supreme Court held in Wells v. Brown, 33 S.W.3d 190 (Mo. 2000) that slipping and falling on an icy parking lot, though not owned, controlled or maintained by employer, was a hazard which was related to an employee's employment where the parking lot was "so situate, designed and used" by the employer and employees incidental to their work. Even though the weather was icy for miles around the building, the court found that the icy condition of the parking lot was a hazard related to the employee's employment because she would not have walked on the lot had she not been going to work. The extent to which the 1993 amendments have modified prior caselaw will be determined by the appellate courts.[4] However, some of the basic rules probably still apply.

 

Under prior caselaw the phrases "arising out of" and "in the course of" employment were two distinct tests; both had to be satisfied in order to establish compensability of injuries. The phrase "in the course of employment" refers to the time, place and circumstances under which the injury occurs. This requirement was satisfied if the accident occurred during the period of employment "at a place where the employee may reasonably be fulfilling the duties of employment." "[A]n injury 'arises out of ' employment if it was a natural and reasonable incident thereof." Auto. Club Inter-Insurance Exch. v. Bevel, 663 S.W.2d 242, 245 (Mo. 1984); Kloppenberg v. Queen Size Shoes, Inc., 704 S.W.2d 234 (Mo. 1986); Toole v. Bechtel Corporation, 291 S.W.2d 874, 880 (Mo. 1956); Mann v. City of Pacific, 850 S.W.2d 12, 15 (Mo. App. 1993); McClain v. Welsh Co. 748 S.W.2d 720 (Mo. App. 1988); Palmer v. H.E. Miller Oldsmobile, Inc., 731 S.W.2d 389 (Mo. App. 1987); Dillard v. City of St. Louis, 685 S.W.2d 918, 922 (Mo. App. 1984); Fingers v. Mount Tabor United Church of Christ, 439 S.W.2d 241 (Mo. App. 1969).

 

For an injury to arise "in the course of employment", it must occur "within the period of employment at a place where the employee may reasonably be, while engaged in the furtherance of the employer's business" or while the employee is "doing an act reasonably incidental to the performance of his duties of which his employer might reasonably have knowledge or reasonably anticipate." Mann v. City of Pacific, 850 S.W.2d 12, 15 (Mo. App. 1993). For an injury to arise "out of employment", there must be "a causal connection between the nature of the employee's duties or the conditions under which he is required to perform them and the resulting injury." Mann at 16-17. The particular injury does not have to be anticipated so long as it is a rational consequence of some hazard connected with work. Toole v. Bechtel Corporation, 291 S.W.2d 874, 880 (Mo. 1956); Dillard v. City of St. Louis, 685 S.W.2d 918, 922 (Mo. App. 1984). The injury must be a natural and reasonable incident of the employment, "a rational consequence of some hazard connected therewith or a risk reasonably inherent in the particular conditions of the employment." In addition, the injury must result from "a risk peculiar to the employment or enhanced thereby." Mann at 16-17. Examples of cases where injuries were held to be noncompensable because the causative agency was a hazard which was not connected with the employment include: Lathrop v. Tobin-Hamilton Shoe Manufacturing. Co., 402 S.W.2d 16 (Mo. App. 1966) (automobile accidentally driven through the window of a building struck the employee) and Williams v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co., 332 S.W.2d 296 (Mo. App. 1960) (tornado caused wall to fall on claimant).

 

Prior to the 1993 amendments assaults were divided into three classes in order to determine whether an ensuing injury "arises out of employment".[5] Allen v. Dorothy's Laundry and Dry Cleaning Co., 523 S.W.2d 874, 878-79 (Mo. App. 1975); Lyons v. Lyons Truck Service, 831 S.W.2d 706, 708-09 (Mo. App. 1992). Those categories are as follows. Injuries resulting from assaults which are "invited by the dangerous nature of the employee's duties, or by the dangerous environment in which he is required to perform them, or are the outgrowth of friction generated by the work itself, but which in either event, are invariably revealed to be the result of some risk directly attributable to the employment" are compensable. Person v. Scullin Steel Company, 523 S.W.2d 801, 803 (Mo. 1975) quoting from Liebman v. Colonial Baking Company, 391 S.W.2d 948, 951 (Mo. App. 1965). In addition, injuries which result from irrational, unexplained or accidental assaults which occur in the course of the employee's employment are also compensable.[6] Section 287.120 (1) Mo. Rev. Stat. (1994); Person at 806; Wolfe v. Dubourg House/Archdiocese of St. Louis, 93 S.W.3d 855, 858 (Mo. App. 2003); Allen v. Dorothy's Laundry and Dry Cleaning Co., 523 S.W.2d 874, 876-79 (Mo. App. 1975). On the other hand, injuries which result from assaults "committed in the course of private quarrels that are purely personal to the participants" are noncompensable. Person at 804, quoting from Liebman v. Colonial Baking Company, 391 S.W.2d 948, 951 (Mo. App. 1965). Accord, Thompson v. Delmar Gardens, Chesterfield, 885 S.W.2d 780, 781 (Mo. App. 1994); Scheper v. Hair Repair, Inc., 825 S.W.2d 1, 3 (Mo. App. 1991); Dillon v. General Motors, 784 S.W.2d 915, 917 (Mo. App. 1990); Luster v. Industrial Engineering & Equipment Co., 747 S.W.2d 228, 229 (Mo. App. 1988); Johnson v. Nanias (Bridal Originals), 738 S.W.2d 164, 165 (Mo. App. 1987); Cramer v. The Wash House of Susquehanna, Inc., 690 S.W.2d 804, 805 (Mo. App. 1985). As previously stated, the foregoing categories determine whether an assault "arises out of employment".

 

Findings of Fact

 

Based on my observations of Brenda Clarks demeanor during her testimony, I find that she is a credible witness and that her testimony is generally credible. Based on my observations of Barry Eikmanns demeanor during his testimony, I find that he is a credible witness and that his testimony is generally credible. I also find the testimony of Mark Ellis, Barry Eikmann, and Richard Kurt, who testified by deposition, is generally credible.[7] Based on the credible testimony of the witnesses, I make the following findings of fact.

 

Mark Manzella shot and killed Kevin Clark while employee was sitting in his automobile parked on the parking lot at Hussmann Corporation just before the commencement of his shift at 7:00 a.m. on June 4, 2001. It was a rainy day. (Stipulation and Claimants Exhibit A) He died as a result of a gunshot wound to the head. (Claimants Exhibit E) Mr. Clark was parked in the main parking lot on the Taussig Road side, the parking lot designated for him, as well as the majority of the production and salary employees at Hussmann Corporation. Mr. Clark was parked in the parking lot where he was expected to park and where he had parked for a number of years while employed at Hussmann Corporation. The parking lot provides a benefit to Hussmann Corporation in that it provides easy access for Hussmann Corporation workers to get in and outside the facility to work, and helps with regard to the workers being on time. (Claimants Exhibits A and B)

 

At the time of his death, Mr. Clark was a sheet metal worker for employer Hussmann Corporation which is in the business of manufacturing refrigeration display cases used in the grocery store and convenience store industry. (Claimants Exhibit B) Mr. Clark had worked for the employer for over twenty years, beginning in April of 1980. (Claimants Exhibit D). For at least ten years prior to the date of his death, Mr. Clark worked the first shift for Hussmann Corporation, from 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.

 

Hussmann Corporation is located at 12999 St. Charles Rock Road, Bridgeton, Missouri on approximately 40 acres. The property is surrounded by St. Charles Rock Road, Taussig Road, Enterprise Way, and railroad tracks and another business. Hussmann Corporation has been at its location since 1967. Hussmann Corporation owns the property where it is located on St. Charles Rock Road, including the parking lot areas which are provided for its employees to park. For many years Hussmann Corporation has employed electricians, mechanics, tool and die workers, sheet metal operators, lift truck operators, and assemblers. As of June 2001 Hussmann Corporation employed approximately 1800 employees, including salaried and hourly workers, at the St. Charles Rock Road site. It employed approximately 1100 unskilled hourly employees, approximately 70 skilled hourly employees, and approximately 630 salaried employees. During its busy season, Hussmann Corporation operates a three shift schedule, the approximate hours of which are 7:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m., 3:00 p.m. to midnight, and 10:30 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. (Claimants Exhibit B)

 

Hussmann Corporation maintains files on its ex-employees, including photo IDs. Specifically, Hussmann Corporation maintained the personnel file of Mark Manzella, an ex-employee of Hussmann Corporation. (Claimants Exhibit B) Mark Manzella worked at Hussmann Corporation from August of 1987 until December of 1997. During that time there were several documented incidents at Hussmann Corporation which evidenced volatile and belligerent behavior by Ms. Manzella towards Hussmann Corporation co-workers over a number of years. Documentation within Mark Manzella's personnel file evidences Hussmann Corporation's knowledge of this behavior, which includes notes regarding Manzella's intimidation of other employees, arguing with other employees, a psychiatric and psychological evaluation of Manzella indicating that while he had no signs of mental illness, he was a very aggressive individual and suggested that he continue with counseling. (Claimants Exhibit V-4) Mark Ellis, who has worked in security for Hussmann Corporation for eleven years, characterized Mr. Manzella as a "hothead" with "a bad temper". He testified that Mr. Manzella was always argumentative and got into altercations with co-employees. (Claimants Exhibit A, Pages 54-55)

 

Mrs. Clark met Mark Manzella through her husband and she had known Mark Manzella and Tammy Manzella for about ten years. The Clarks attended the Manzellas wedding. The Clarks and Manzellas were friends, until the friendship was interrupted by a love affair between Mr. Clark and Mrs. Manzella, who also worked for Hussmann Corporation. (Testimony of Brenda Clark)

 

In early November, 2000, Brenda Clark discovered that her husband was having an affair with Mrs. Manzella. Mark Manzella contacted Mrs. Clark to tell her about the affair and he also told her that Mrs. Manzella and Mr. Clark were having sexual relations. Mr. Manzella was angry and jealous and, in a later conversation with Mrs. Clark, Mr. Manzella threatened to put a bullet in Mr. Clarks head. Mr. Clark admitted to his wife that he was having an affair with Mrs. Manzella. Although Mr. Clark had told his wife that the affair with Mrs. Manzella had ended, Mrs. Clark was not sure whether the affair was ongoing at the time Mr. Clark died, because Mr. Clark had previously stated that the affair was over, when it had not appeared to be over. (Testimony of Brenda Clark)

 

Ken Zerkel, Mr. Clarks brother-in-law, who also worked at Hussmann Corporation, knew several months before Mr. Clark died that Mr. Manzella had threatened Mr. Clark. Mr. Zerkel considered Mr. Manzellas animosity a family matter and did not share that information with the employer. (Testimony of Brenda Clark)

 

After her husband died, Mrs. Clark checked her husbands cell phone for messages. Before Mr. Clark died, Mr. Manzella had left a message on Mr. Clarks cell phone which demanded that Mr. Clark meet Mr. Manzella at the house, at work, or in front of the kids. (Testimony of Brenda Clark)

 

 

 

 

Additional Findings

 

Employer/insurer contend that Mr. Clark died as a result of a personal quarrel over his meretricious romance with Mrs. Manzella. Claimants contend that Mr. Clarks death resulted from an irrational or unexplained assault.

 

Evidence of a personal motive for an assault usually favors its categorization as a noncompensable personal quarrel. Such cases usually involve assaults by a co-employee or third party because of disputes over personal or business relationships extrinsic to employment. In some cases the assailant's motive was inferred from circumstantial evidence; in others contemporaneous statements made by the assailant were in evidence. (E.g. Foster v. Aines Farm Dairy Co., 263 S.W.2d 421, 429 (Mo. 1953) (personal hatred and jealousies engendered in parties by their personal, family, and business relationships other than due to employment); Cramer v. The Wash House of Susquehanna, Inc., 690 S.W.2d 804, 805 (Mo. App. 1985) (murder was an act of revenge by a cuckolded husband); Freeman v. Callow, 525 S.W.2d 371, 376 (Mo. App. 1975) (act of revenge of a jealous husband who mistakenly thought he had been cuckolded); Dillon v. General Motors, 784 S.W.2d 915, 916 (Mo. App. 1990) (anger over female employee telling assailant to keep his hands off her and calling him "'anti-social.'"); Thompson v. Delmar Gardens, Chesterfield, 885 S.W.2d 780, 781 (Mo. App. 1994) (admission by assailant that he assaulted claimant because claimant have given assailant's girlfriend, a co-employee of claimant, a ride home from work); Scheper v. Hair Repair, Ltd., 825 S.W.2d 1, 3 (Mo. App. 1991) (prior pattern of violent conduct and animosity of deceased's former boyfriend); Luster v. Industrial Engineering and Equipment Company, 747 S.W.2d 228, 229 (Mo. App. 1988) (arguments between co-employees over sports and girls); Lardge v. Concrete Products Mfg. Co. 251 S.W.2d 49, 52 (Mo. 1952) (argument over assailant's alleged theft of bottle of wine deceased employee brought to work); Johnson v. Nanias (Bridal Originals), 738 S.W.2d 164, 165 (Mo. App. 1987) (money allegedly owed by one employee to another employee).

 

The absence of evidence of any motive for an assault usually favors its categorization as irrational, unexplained or accidental. Section 287.120 (1) Mo. Rev. Stat. (1994); Person v. Scullin Steel Company, 523 S.W.2d 801, 806 (Mo. 1975); Wolfe v. Dubourg House/Archdiocese of St. Louis, 93 S.W.3d 855, 858 (Mo. App. 2003) (assault by co-worker who accused victim of not liking her, which victim denied found to be unexplained); Lyons v. Lyons Truck Service, 831 S.W.2d 706, 708-09 (Mo. App. 1992) (truck driver murdered while staying overnight in motel; no evidence of any motive); Olivio v. TLI, Inc., 731 S.W.2d 395 (Mo. App. 1987) (truck driver assaulted while sleeping in his truck cab by passenger; no evidence of any motive); Zahn v. Associated Dry Goods, 655 S.W.2d 769 (Mo. App. 1983) (employee raped in employers parking garage by unknown assailant); Allen v. Dorothy's Laundry and Dry Cleaning Co., 523 S.W.2d 874, 876-79 (Mo. App. 1975) (employee shot by berserk rifleman for no apparent reason).

 

The motive for the assault in this case is known. This was not an assault for no apparent reason. Based on my prior findings, I find that the assault in this case was an act of revenge by a cuckolded husband. In November of 2000 Mr. Manzella told Mrs. Clark that her husband was having an affair with his wife. When confronted by Mrs. Clark about the affair, Mr. Clark admitted it, but claimed that it had ended. She later came to suspect that the affair was continuing. In a subsequent conversation with Mrs. Clark, Mr. Manzella threatened to put a bullet in Mr. Clarks head. On the day he murdered Mr. Clark, Mr. Manzella left a message on Mr. Clarks cell phone which demanded that Mr. Clark meet Mr. Manzella at the house, at work, or in front of the kids. Shortly, thereafter he shot Mr. Clark in the head.

 

Based on my finding that the motive for the assault in this case was an act of revenge by a cuckolded husband, I find that the assault was committed in the course of a private quarrel that was purely personal to the participants and consequently did not arise out of claimants employment with Hussmann Corporation and is therefore noncompensable. Cramer v. The Wash House of Susquehanna, Inc., 690 S.W.2d 804, 805 (Mo. App. 1985). The claim is denied.

 

 

 

 

 

Date: _________________________________ Made by: __________________________________

John Howard Percy

Administrative Law Judge

Division of Workers' Compensation

A true copy: Attest:

 

_________________________________

Rene T. Slusher

Director

Division of Workers' Compensation

 

 

 

 

 


[1] Employer/insurer did not contest that Mr. Clarks death occurred in the course of employees employment.

[2] An injury is clearly work related "if work was a substantial factor in the cause of the resulting medical condition or disability. An injury is not compensable merely because work was a triggering or precipitating factor." The Supreme Court held in Kasl v. Bristol Care, Inc., 984 S.W.2d 501 (Mo. 1999) that the foregoing language overruled the holdings in Wynn v. Navajo Freight Lines, Inc., 654 S.W.2d 87 (Mo. 1983), Bone v. Daniel Hamm Drayage Company, 449 S.W.2d 169 (Mo. 1970), and many other cases which had allowed an injury to be compensable so long as it was "triggered or precipitated" by work. Injuries which are triggered or precipitated by work may nevertheless be compensable if the work is found to be a "substantial factor" in causing the injury. Kasl, supra. A substantial factor does not have to be the primary or most significant causative factor. Cahall v. Cahall, 963 S.W.2d 368, 372 (Mo. App. 1998). An accident may be both a triggering event and a substantial factor in causing an injury. Id. Subsection 2 also provides that an injury must be incidental and not independent of employment relationship and that "ordinary, gradual deterioration or progressive degeneration of the body caused by aging" is not compensable unless it "follows as an incident of employment." The parties stipulated that Kevin Clark was shot and killed by Mark Manzella.

[3] In construing subsection (2)(d) the Supreme Court held in Kasl v. Bristol Care, Inc., 984 S.W.2d 501 (Mo. 1999) that "'idiopathic conditions, those peculiar to the individual: innate'" were among those hazards or risks which were "unrelated to the employment". The court also stated that "common conditions which [are] exacerbated by employment requirements are not idiopathic." The Supreme Court further held that falling while getting up from a chair at work, so long as the fall is not caused by an idiopathic condition, is not a risk which is unrelated to employment. In Drewes v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., 984 S.W.2d 501 (Mo. 1999) the Supreme Court appears to have held activities previously compensable under the "personal comfort doctrine" to be incidents of employment under the 1993 amendments. The court held that falling while carrying one's lunch to a table in a break room open to all tenants of an office building is not a risk which was unrelated to claimant's employment, even where the cause of the fall is unexplained.

The court appears to have largely abandoned its decision in Abel v. Mike Russell's Standard Service, 924 S.W.2d 502 (Mo. 1996), where a claim was denied because a gas station attendant could not explain why he fainted while pumping gas, by consigning it to cases occurring before the effective date of the 1993 amendments.

[4] For a time there was speculation that subsection 3(2)(d) had revived the "greater risk or hazard" test which was largely abandoned in Ford Motor Co. v. Dickens, 700 S.W.2d 484, 486-87 (Mo. App. 1985) and Alexander v. D.L. Sitton Motor Lines, 851 S.W.2d 525, 528-29 (Mo. 1993). The decisions in Kasl and Wells suggest that the Supreme Court intends to construe hazards unrelated to employment very narrowly.

[5] It is clear from the many cases discussing in which class a particular assault fell that the issue was whether the assault "arose out of employment". In most cases there was no issue of whether the assault arose "in the course of employment" as the incidents usually took place at the workplace. Claimants the discussion of the cases listed in each class of assault in Person v. Scullin Steel Company, 523 S.W.2d 801, 803-04 (Mo. 1975). Where the assault occurred away from the workplace the courts have undertaken a separate analysis of the time, place and circumstances under which the injury occurred. E.g. Toole v. Bechtel Corporation, 291 S.W.2d 874, 879 (Mo. 1956); Beem v. H.D. Lee Mercantile Co., 85 S.W.2d 441, 444-45 (Mo. 1935); Lyons v. Lyons Truck Service, 831 S.W.2d 706, 708 (Mo. App. 1992); Hacker v. City of Potosi, 340 S.W.2d 166, 170-72 (Mo. App. 1960); Staten v. Long-Turner Const. Co., 185 S.W.2d 375, 380-81 (Mo. App. 1945).

[6] Prior to a 1969 amendment to Section 287.120 this category was noncompensable under the theory that although the injury occurred in the course of the victim's employment, it could not be attributable to the employment [i.e. arise out of employment] "on any more rational basis than that the employment afforded a convenient occasion for the attack to take place." Person v. Scullin Steel Company, 523 S.W.2d 801, 804 (Mo. 1975) quoting from Liebman v. Colonial Baking Company, 391 S.W.2d 948, 951 (Mo. App. 1965). The 1969 amendment made that category of assaults compensable by eliminating the necessity for an affirmative showing that the assault arose out of employment. It did not eliminate the necessity for an affirmative showing that the assault arose in the course of employment. Allen v. Dorothy's Laundry and Dry Cleaning Co., 523 S.W.2d 874, 878-79 (Mo. App. 1975); accord, Person at 806.

[7] Employer/insurers relevancy objections to the admissibility of these depositions are overruled.

Baldrige in Education:
How Quality Managment is Transforming
School Systems and Improving Student Performace
A Forum Brief — April 28, 2000

Malcolm Baldrige, the late Secretary of Commerce under President Reagan, "started a competition for companies that involved management and workers alike in a relentless drive for quality and customer satisfaction . . . Winning the Baldrige became the most prestigious honor in American business, and the systematic effort to set organizational goals and measure progress became pervasive."

—David S. Broder, The Washington Post, July 14, 1999

Congress created the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award in 1987 to recognize U.S. companies and organizations for their achievements in quality and performance, and to raise awareness about the power of quality management to tap the full potential of American businesses. In 1998 Congress authorized an expansion of the award to include educational institutions. School districts are beginning to apply for Baldrige Awards, and though a few have reached finalist status, none have received this highly competitive honor to date. The American Youth Policy Forum (AYPF) sponsored a forum on Capitol Hill to inform policymakers and educators about the lessons that schools have learned in striving to meet the criteria of the Baldrige Award.

Our first speaker was Peggy Siegel, the Director of Business/Education Initiatives for the National Alliance of Business (NAB). Siegel discussed NAB’s partnership with the American Productivity & Quality Center (APQC) in forming the Baldrige in Education Initiative (BiE IN—pronounced "buy in") in 1999. The twenty-six leading companies and educational organizations that make up BiE IN have spurred a nationwide reform effort using the Baldrige Award criteria to raise student achievement. Award nominees are judged on leadership, strategic planning, data collection and analysis, human resource development, and results. These criteria, according to Siegel, respect the capacity of front-line teaching staff and students to improve the quality of their own educational institutions given clear goals and sufficient data.

Educators and their business partners who have tried to follow the Baldrige criteria in reforming schools echo Siegel’s claims for the potential of quality management. Brenda Clark, Principal of Azalea Elementary School and Doug Smith, Principal of Osceola High School, work in the Pinellas County School District in Florida. In striving to meet the Baldrige criteria, the Pinellas District won Florida’s Sterling Award for quality in education. Clark and Smith spoke about how these business techniques and quality management strategies actually work on the educational front lines.

At Azalea Elementary, the Baldrige strategies invested teachers and students in the reform process and the standards movement. According to Principal Clark, teachers and students now create classroom data systems to measure and foster academic success. When asked how the school approached behavior management, Clark described helping the students create bar graphs to chart bus referrals for bad behavior, so that they could analyze and learn from the buses that maintained order and ran smoothly. This and other quality management techniques contributed to a 20% increase in student test scores at Azalea over a two-year period. The rise in student achievement convinced Lisa Deprez, who works with Azalea’s business partner, the Raytheon Corporation, to transfer her son to Azalea from another public school that is considered "elite," but is not quality driven.

For Osceola High School’s principal, Doug Smith, the use of the business strategies and quality management techniques in the Baldrige criteria was a tough sell. But Smith has been recently converted with the help of Osceola’s business partners, people like Star Glock, Staffing Specialist at GTE. GTE won the Baldrige Award for its business practices in 1994, and the educational arm of the award inspired the company to partner with Osceola High School after several graduates with the equivalent of 9th grade skills applied for GTE’s entry level positions. GTE helped Osceola collect data on achievement and target areas where quality management could improve student success. According to Principal Smith, the data and quality management strategies helped align expectations of success for business leaders, school administrators, teachers, parents, and students. Along with the help collecting data, GTE also hosted hundreds of Osceola students at the company offices for training in effective business practices and helped a smaller group create a student-run greeting card company. These efforts by GTE and the students and staff at Osceola paid off. The business partnership and Baldrige criteria helped increase student pass rates from 68% to 84% on the Florida Comprehensive Assessment Test (FCAT) in mathematics and 61% to 78% on the FCAT in reading between 1998 and 1999.

The addition of an educational component to the Baldrige Award has already begun to have a positive impact on schools. In part, this is due to the healthy injection of old fashioned business acumen in educational reform strategies. The Baldrige Award’s educational arm has also fostered a new attitude in the business community toward school partnerships and brought recognition to the role of young people as critical actors in developing their own educational experiences. These new strategies and partnerships hold exciting potential for improving the quality of American education.

Ag Econ-O-Gram

July 9, 2004

FACULTY MEETING
The Department faculty meeting is not scheduled at this time.

LAND MANAGEMENT OFFICE ASSISTANT DIRECTOR
The Land Management Office (Room 109 Ag. Hall) is pleased to announce the appointment of Ms. Brenda Clark to Assistant Director.  The duties of assistant director will be split between Mr. Benjamin Darling and Ms. Clark.  Ben Darling will focus on the areas of construction,
GIS-property mapping, and health, safety and regulatory issues.  Brenda Clark will focus on the areas of real estate transactions and inventory, leases and easement, and space management.

AG EXPO
This AG EXPO marks its 25th year at MSU.  The Ag Expo is Michigan's largest farm show in 35acre exhibit area on the MSU campus on July 20 to 22 (9 to 5, 9 to 8, & 9 to 3). More than 90% of field crop income, livestock income and net farm income is produced within a two hour drive; 250 commercial & educational exhibits; daily field demonstrations on: manure management land application and farming with animals.  Free admission and parking. Take advantage of the draft horse or tractor wagon shuttles to the main exhibition site. The event sponsored by the Dept of Agricultural Engineering.
Attractions will again include MSU's "education row", a cluster of exhibits at the west end of the show site representing departments from the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources. Representatives will be on hand to answer questions about animal health care, farm security, beneficial effects of soil quality, gardening display, farm business software, etc. For more information, go to: http://www.agexpo.msu.edu/visitors.html

FOR SALE
Retired faculty member has 1988 Honda Accord, 4-door sedan, 148,000 miles for sale. Power steering and brakes, good running condition, two new tires, minor rust spots on otherwise good body. Heater works well; air conditioning does not. $1200.  Contact Ann Robinson (355-4569, robins60@msu.edu) for more details.

NEW FACULTY PUBLICATIONS
Horan, R.D. and E.H. Bulte . 2004. Optimal and Open Access Harvesting of Multi-Use Species in a Second-Best World. Environmental and Resource Economics, 28(3)251-272.
Horan, R.D., J.S. Shortle, and D.G. Abler.   2004.  "The Coordination and Design of Point-Nonpoint Trading Programs and Agri-Environmental Policies."  Agricultural and Resource Economics Review, 33(1)61-78.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY
This message announces a new funding opportunity sponsored by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's National Center for Environmental Research (NCER).  To learn more about this Science to Achieve Results (STAR) grant program, visit:  http://es.epa.gov/ncer/ .  Title: Valuation for Environmental Policy.  URL: http://es.epa.gov/ncer/rfa/2004/2004_valuation.html ;  Open Date: 6/24/2004; Close Date: 9/28/2004.
Summary:  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Office of Research and Development (ORD) as part of its Science to Achieve Results (STAR) program, is seeking applications proposing research in three areas studies developing values, functions, and models for estimating the economic value of policy-relevant changes to ecological benefits associated with aquatic resources; studies developing or improving benefit transfer methods for ecological resources; and studies improving primary economic valuation methods. --Will Wheeler, Ph.D., Economist, U.S. EPA, ORD-NCER, (202) 343-9828,  wheeler.william@epa.gov

DAY TRIP FOR KIDS
Looking for a weekend day trip for the kids?  How about sending them 370 million years into the past?  The Fossil Park on the outskirts of Sylvania, Ohio (about two hours from Lansing) is great fun for little treasure hunters--you can keep as many fossils as you can haul out.  I took my nine year old recently, and she loved it.  The price is right (free) and there are four or five affordable, kid-friendly restaurants near the park entrance.  Access this site for directions and a more complete description:  http://www.ohio.com/mld/ohio/entertainment/visitors_guide/3545870.htm?1c --Scott Loveridge

MICHIGAN LAND USE INSTITUTE is looking for a full-time accomplished writer & project coordinator to conserve farmland, grow jobs, and enrich communities by advocating for agricultural entrepreneurs and community-based food systems in Michigan. The writer/coordinators primary charge is to strengthen the Entrepreneurial Agriculture Projects on-the-ground work in northwest Lower Michigan, including a farm-to-cafeteria initiative with area schools, a local food marketing campaign, and a broadening coalition of business, agriculture, and community interests. This involves working closely with the projects director to communicate through research, journalism, advocacy, and marketing the rural development potential and policy imperatives of sustainable, entrepreneurial agriculture and community-based food systems. ________________ CM . . . . Volume III Number 1 . . . . September 6, 1996

Franklin's Halloween.

Paulette Bourgeois. Illustrated by Brenda Clark.
Toronto: Kids Can Press Ltd, 1996. 32 pp., $4.95.PB, $12.95 HC.
ISBN 1-55074-285-X.

Grades K - 3 / Ages 5 - 8.
Review by Brian Rountree.

****/4

The adventures of Franklin are really coming "fast and furious" from the fertile imagination of Paulette Bourgeois. Here she records the fun which Franklin and his friends have at a community Halloween party. It is complete with games and prizes and a haunted house in the yard.

This is Franklin's 13th book and it is fitting that the superstitious number and the festival fit together. Franklin enjoys himself, as all children do, and manages to solve the mystery of the ghost, but not before he is as frightened as everyone else: Bear is always the ghost, but stayed home this year because of a cold. Franklin is sorry that his friend missed out on the fun and arranges for everyone to share in making up a Halloween bag of goodies for Bear.

Clark's illustrations of Franklin and his family and friends continue to be bright and cheerful. Her costumes for Franklin to try on are quite colourful and flamboyant. His final choice is well done and frightens his father (or is he just pretending?) Clark also pays attention to details not given in the text, such as the mice going trick-or-treating at the same time.

Primary grade children enjoy reading Franklin's stories (to Franklin himself, if you have one!) and this Halloween story will swiftly become another favourite.

Recommended

Brian Rountree is the teacher-librarian at Eastwood Elementary School in Thompson, Manitoba. He is the Archivist for the Manitoba School Library Association.

The Franklin Children’s Garden:

A Landscape for Learning on the Toronto Islands

The Franklin Children’s Garden is being built on the Toronto Islands and is scheduled to open in 2005. The garden is inspired by Franklin the Turtle; the star of the popular storybooks published by Kids Can Press, a Corus Entertainment company. They are written by Paulette Bourgeois and illustrated by Brenda Clark.

The Franklin Children’s Garden will provide a hands-on outdoor environment where children can learn about the natural world and enjoy the great adventure of reading -- something that will enhance the rest of their lives. It will be an ideal place for children, families and school classes to have fun as they experience the joys of reading and learn more about nature.

Garden Map (click to enlarge)

The garden, designed by Toronto Parks and Recreation and landscape architecture firms of Schollen & Company Inc., and Janet Rosenberg & Associates, is approximately four acres and has several areas in which visitors will enjoy hands-on features. The garden will include:

  • Franklin’s Pine Grove – bronze sculptures of Franklin and his storybook friends to be created by Canadian Sculptor Ruth Abernethy
  • TD Storybook Place – a stage and amphitheatre seating for storytelling performances
  • Kids Can Press Little Sprouts Garden – a hands-on gardening feature for children
  • Unilever Snail Trail -- elevated feature with trails and a lookout over the wetland
  • Hide & Seek Garden – architectural hide and seek features including a treehouse and garden maze
  • Turtle Pond – 1.92 acres (1.2 acres of land and .71 acres of water) wetland designed for turtles, amphibians, fish, and birds.

The Franklin Children’s Garden is being made possible through the generosity of :

Leadership Donors

Major Donor
Donors
Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark
